column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Other manufacturing
column4: Manufacture of medical and dental instruments and supplies
column7: ND
column9: Manufacturing of medical and dental instruments and supplies can release greenhouse gases emissions from manufacturing and production processes contributing to air pollution.
column11: Chemical substances used for manufacturing, and waste from production processes can impact on natural environments, including atmosphere.
column14: Manufacturing of medical and dental instruments can produce toxic or hazardous substances, particularly mercury, from its products, leading to soil and water contamination, impacting the environment.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: ND
column18: Water is important in all stages of medical device processing. Water is required for each step in the decontamination process, from soaking to manual or automated cleaning to rinsing, including the final disinfecting rinse. Furthermore, even concentrated instrument cleaners are composed primarily of water, the solvent for all chemicals in the solution.

column3: Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment
column4: Manufacture of other fabricated metal products; metalworking service activities
column7: Manufacture of other fabricated metal products; metalworking service activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacture of other fabricated metal products; metalworking service activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from firing temperatures ranging from 800 to 2000 °C, which involves fossil fuel combustion and carbonate reaction in a kiln, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Manufacturing processes lead to non-product outputs, which include liquid or gaseous emissions, and waste material, some of which is reused or recycled. Other forms of pollution may occur as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals.
column14: Manufacturing processes of other fabricated metal products can include liquid and waste material, such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals. Chemical discharge, improper waste disposal, and landfill practices of the economic activity can contaminate the soil and water with toxic substances.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: The primary use of land in the manufacture of other fabricated metal products; metalworking service activities is for manufacturing plants.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Other manufacturing
column7: Other manufacturing n.e.c. processes can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Other manufacturing activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from the machine level, transport, production, and disposal of material, tools, and consumable contributing to air pollution.
column11: Chemical substances used for manufacturing, and waste from production processes can impact on natural environments, including atmosphere.
column14: Manufacturing processes can release toxic substances and chemical waste, leading to soil and water contamination, impacting the environment.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment
column4: Manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators
column7: Manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators can release greenhouse gases through energy use to achieve the high temperatures required for this economic activity. Where the factories are powered using on-site energy generators, these produce significant greenhouse gas emissions.
column11: The manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators involves stages that can release non-greenhouse gas (non-GHG) emissions into the environment including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
column14: Improper waste management practices during the manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators can cause soil pollution. Chemical discharge, improper waste disposal, and landfill practices can contaminate the soil and water with toxic substances and contribute to pollution.
column16: Manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators can result in the generation of solid waste including leftover chemicals, byproducts, packaging materials, and process residues.
column17: The primary use of land in the manufacture of structural metal products, tanks, reservoirs and steam generators is for manufacturing plants.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Repair and installation of machinery and equipment
column4: Installation of industrial machinery and equipment
column7: Installation of industrial machinery and equipment can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Installation of industrial machinery and equipment can release greenhouse gases emissions during the manufacture process, especially in the manufacturing of semicondutors, contributing air pollution.
column10: The installation process for industrial machinery and equipment onto the seabed can result in the release of sediments and increased turbidity in the water column, as well as changes to hydrological characteristics.
column11: Industrial machinery and equipment, such as combustion engines, boilers, and incinerators, can release airborne pollutants, such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
column14: Industrial machinery and equipment, such as combustion engines, boilers, and incinerators, can release airborne pollutants that settle onto the soil and water, leading to contamination.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Industrial machinery and equipment installations may require land clearance.  Industrial machinery installation can result in the destruction or fragmentation of natural habitats.
column18: Industrial machinery and equipment often require a significant amount of water for their operation. This can lead to increased water consumption, extraction of groundwater and withdrawal from freshwater sources for cooling or other purposes, which can strain local water supplies and potentially deplete water sources in the area. Excessive pumping of groundwater can lead to its depletion, causing lowered water tables, reduced streamflow, and potentially drying up nearby wells or springs, which can have significant consequences for local communities and ecosystems reliant on groundwater resources.
column19: The installation of industrial machinery and equipment can lead to habitat disturbance, such as land clearing or alteration of water bodies. These disturbances can create new ecological niches or disrupt existing ecosystems, providing opportunities for invasive species to establish themselves.

column3: Printing and reproduction of recorded media
column7: Reproduction of recorded media can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery and reproduction processes that can disrupt or negatively affect species in surrounding areas.
column9: N/A
column11: N/A
column14: N/A
column16: Reproduction of recorded media may produce a marginal amount of waste.
column17: ND
column18: Water is used in CD replication, as well as for cooling purposes.

column3: Repair and installation of machinery and equipment
column4: Repair of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment
column7: Repair of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment can cause disturbances due to exposed to high levels of electromagnetic fields that can disrupt or negatively affect species in local areas.
column9: Repair of personal and household goods can release greenhouse gases emissions from breakdown of insulating oils in power transformers, energy used for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities and equipment, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Repair of electrical equipment could include underwater cables on the seabed requiring repair.
column11: The gaseous waste and discharges from facilities as well as backup power generators used to operate equipment can emit non-greenhouse gases.
column14: Repair of fabricated metal products, machinery and equipment potentially pollute soil and water due to insulating oil leakage as power transformers age.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as oil and oil filters, and batteries. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Pylons and overhead cables occupy land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Repair processes can require volumes of water for cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of basic metals
column4: Manufacture of basic iron and steel
column7: The manufacture of basic iron and steel can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations, and lead to displacement of species. There may also may be a risk of flying particles, sparks and optical radiation.
column9: Manufacturing of basic iron and steel can release greenhouse gases emissions (e.g. nitrous oxide, carbon dioxide) from highly energy intensive operations, which in some cases uses a large amount of coal coke and natural gas, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Iron/steel plants emit carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, and fugitive dust during equipment operation. Blast furnaces release most of the particulate matter (PM), while sinter plants produce gaseous pollutants and the majority of PCDD/Fs. Steelmaking processes generate heavy metal emissions (Pb, Cd, Hg, As, Cr, Ni, etc.) and highly toxic substances like coke and naphthalene.
column14: Soils in the vicinity of steel plants have been shown to exhibit high concentrations of heavy metals as well as persistent organic pollutants. The iron and steel industry discharges large quantities of wastewater with critical pollutants such as cadmium, copper and mercury releasing them into water courses.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs iron ore tailings, blast furnace slags, and steel slags. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: The primary use of land in the manufacture of basic iron and steel is for manufacturing plants.
column18: Iron plants use large quantities of water for steam generation, cooling, waste transfer, and dust control. This water is often directly extracted from water sources such as rivers. The water used contributes to  water stress, especially in areas where water resources are already limited.

column3: Other manufacturing
column4: Manufacture of jewellery, bijouterie and related articles
column7: Manufacture of jewellery, bijouterie and related articles can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of jewellery, bijouterie and related articles can release greenhouse gases emissions through electricity and liquefied petroleum gas consumption, being responsible for 30% of GHG emissions of the full lifecycle of its activities and contributing to air pollution.
column11: Manufacturing processes can release non-GHG emissions into the environment, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs). Pollution may occur as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals.
column14: Pollution may occur from the manufacture of jewellery, bijouterie and related articles, as a result of using certain materials, substances and liquid emissions (i.e., acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals).
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacture of jewellery, bijouterie and related articles uses a significant amount of water for cleaning, polishing, and assembling the pieces. The water used contributes to  water stress, especially in areas where water resources are already limited.

column3: Education
column7: Pre-primary and primary education can cause disturbances such as noise pollution from classrooms noise, which can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Pre-primary and primary education activities using buildings can release greenhouse gases emissions from heating, lighting and ventilation of the school buildings, contributing to air pollution. If using school buses, these also contribute to the generation of GHG emissions.
column11: Pre-primary and primary education conducted from buildings can produce significant non-GHG emissions as well as emissions associated with cooling, refrigeration, or insulation materials.
column14: If using buildings and facilities, education activities produce waste and discharges that without a proper disposal, can be emitted into the surrounding environment, leaching toxic substances into the soil and groundwater, affecting soil and water bodies.
column15: Science experiments in education programmes can result in contamination of soil and water with nutrient pollutants if waste is not disposed of properly.
column16: Educational activities generate waste, including paper waste, packaging materials and electronic waste.
column17: Educational activities that use buildings and facilities occupy land. Moreover, educational activities demand for supporting infrastructure, which can lead to additional land use change.
column18: Educational activities, such as research projects, laboratories, and vocational training programs, involve water-intensive processes or experiments. These activities require large volumes of water for purposes such as sanitary facilities, drinking, irrigation, cooling systems, chemical reactions, or cleaning, thereby contributing to increased water consumption.

column3: Manufacture of other transport equipment
column7: Building of ships and boats can cause disturbances like noise and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g. during ship and boat building processes), which can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column9: Building of ships and boats can release greenhouse gases emissions from production processes such as electric arc welding contributing to air pollution.
column11: Gases and particulates from ship and boat production processes such as welding, like magansese and chromium cause hazardous air pollutants.
column14: The building of ships and boats uses anti-fouling paints which contain toxic compounds and can lead to pollution of the environment.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as steel, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: ND
column18: The building of ships and boats and their facilities use water throughout their operations, for example surface water is used to cool the machinery during production. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column11: Gases and particulates from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling contribute to air pollution. Additionally, harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Use of toxic materials in the manufacturing of air and space craft, such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, and solders, can lead to pollution of natural habitats. column16: Manufacturing processes for air and spacecraft leads to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, and electrical components. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.

column9: Manufacturing of special-purpose machinery can contribute to greenhouse gases emissions from the manufacturing processes and the assembly plant. Cooling and heating systems of facilities consuming energy produced by the burning of fossil fuels can also contribute to greenhouse emissions.
column11: Harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Manufacture of special-purpose machinery can release hazardous waste such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals, which can lead to soil and water pollution.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste, including non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, off-cuts, refractories, slags, sludges, fluxes, lubricating fluids and baghouse and electrostatic precipitator waste. column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.

column3: Manufacture of electrical equipment
column7: Manufacture of domestic appliances can cause disturbances like  noise pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of domestic appliances can release emissions of GHG during the manufacture process, especially in the manufacturing of semicondutors, which can lead to air pollution.
column11: Harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Many chemicals are used in domestic appliances production, which could lead to pollution of soil and water.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Mianufacturing of domestic appliances can cause land degradation, including soil erosion, loss of topsoil, and alteration of natural drainage patterns. These activities can result in the destruction of fertile land and disrupt local ecosystems. Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column7: Manufacture of furniture can cause disturbances like dust and  noise pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.

Wastewater from cooling and cleaning processes can also lead to increased toxicity in soil and aquatic environments.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.

column7: Manufacture of military fighting vehicles can cause disturbances like noise, light  and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to  habitat fragmentation.

column11: Gases and particulates from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling contribute to air pollution. Additionally, harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Use of toxic and persistent materials in the manufacture of military fighting vehicles can lead to pollution of the environment, as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals. Wastewater from cooling and cleaning processes can also lead to increased toxicity in soil and aquatic environments.
column16: Manufacturing processes for military fighting vehicles  leads to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, and electrical components. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.

column3: Manufacture of motor vehicles, trailers and semi-trailers
column7: Manufacture of motor vehicles can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery  and vehicles and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of motor vehicles can contribute to greenhouse gases emissions from the manufacturing processes, which is extremely energy-intensive, since it requires the extraction of raw materials such as steel, aluminum, plastic, and rubber.
column11: Harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Manufacturing of motor vehicles can produce toxic waste from paint residues, used oils and sorbents, lead-acid batteries, and automotive chemicals like antifreeze and refrigerants, which can lead to soil and water pollution.
column16: Manufacturing of parts and accessories for motor vehicles can produce different types of solid waste such as lead-acid batteries, lead wheel weights, fluorescent lamps and waste paint products (e.g. paint thinner and paint booth filters), as well as other waste such as packaging, wood and plastics. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of other transport equipment
column7: Manufacture of transport equipment n.e.c. can cause disturbances like noise, light  and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to  habitat fragmentation.
column9: Manufacturing of transport equipment can release greenhouse gases emissions from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Gases and particulates from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling contribute to air pollution. Additionally, harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Use of toxic materials in the manufacture of transport equipment (such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders), can lead to pollution of the environment, due to wastewater that is generated from cooling and cleaning processes that interact with these materials and can lead to increased toxicity in soil and aquatic environments.
column16: Manufacturing processes for transport equipment leads to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, and electrical components. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column4: Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles
column7: Manufacture of parts and accessories for motor vehicles can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery  and vehicles and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of parts and accessories for motor vehicles can contribute to greenhouse gases emissions from the manufacturing processes, which is extremely energy-intensive, since it requires the extraction of raw materials such as steel, aluminum, plastic, and rubber.
column11: Harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Manufacturing of parts and accessories for motor vehicles can produce toxic waste from paint residues, used oils and sorbents, lead-acid batteries, and automotive chemicals like antifreeze and refrigerants, which can lead to soil and water pollution.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste, including non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, off-cuts, refractories, slags, sludges, fluxes, lubricating fluids and baghouse and electrostatic precipitator waste. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of other transport equipment
column4: Manufacture of railway locomotives and rolling stock
column7: Manufacture of railway locomotives and rolling stock can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column9: Manufacturing of railway locomotives and rolling stock can release greenhouse gases emissions from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Gases and particulates from manufacturing and production processes such as burning coal and cooling contribute to air pollution. Additionally, harmful chemicals may be emitted into the atmosphere such as sulphur and nitrogen oxides, which impact the environment through acid rain.
column14: Use of toxic materials in the manufacture of railway locomotives and rolling stock (such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders), can lead to pollution of the environment, due to wastewater that is generated from cooling and cleaning processes that interact with these materials and can lead to increased toxicity in soil and aquatic environments.
column16: Manufacturing processes for railway locomotives and rolling stock lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of fabricated metal products, except machinery and equipment
column7: The manufacture of weapons and ammunition can cause disturbances like noise and light due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas.
column9: Manufacturing of weapons and ammunition can release greenhouse gases through energy use to achieve the high temperatures required for this economic activity. Where the factories are powered using on-site energy generators, these produce significant greenhouse gas emissions
column11: The manufacture of weapons and ammunition can release non-greenhouse gas (non-GHG) emissions into the environment including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
column14: Chemical discharge, improper waste disposal, and landfill practices during the manufacture of weapons and ammunition processes can contaminate the soil and water bodies with toxic substances and contribute to pollution.
column16: The manufacture of weapons and ammunition can result in the generation of solid waste as byproducts, including leftover chemicals, byproducts, packaging materials, and process residues. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: The primary use of land in the manufacture of weapons and ammunition is for manufacturing plants
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Biomass energy production can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations such as altering migration patterns.
column9: Biomass energy production through direct combustion (burning) can release greenhouse gases, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Biomass energy production through direct combustion (burning) results in emissions of air pollutants.
column12: Timber derived products can be used as a source of biomass. Some biomass energy producers extract timber from ecosystems.
column14: Biomass energy production can release soil pollutants (e.g. biomass char, soot and tars). Additionally, biomass energy production through direct combustion (burning) results in water pollution due to emissions of suspended solids and trace metals in wastewater.
column15: Some types of biomass energy production can release nutrient pollutants into soil (i.e. release of ammonia when stored or spread on land).
column16: Biomass energy production results in solid waste (e.g. ash) through direct combustion (burning).
column17: Biomass energy facilities occupy land.
column18: Biomass energy production is a water-intensive process, requiring about 2,000 to 20,000 litres of water to produce one litre of biofuel. Biomass energy production uses water for a variety of purposes, including processing biomass into biofuels.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Fossil fuels energy production can cause disturbances like noise pollution from operations (i.e. intermittent and continuous sounds). Light pollution can also occur due to facilities that are lightened at night. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations such as altering migration patterns.
column8: When water is used for cooling system purposes, water withdrawal mechanisms from freshwater sources can affect areas of freshwater ecosystems and can harm or kill aquatic species.
column9: Fossil fuels energy production can release large volumes of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases when burned, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Fossil fuels energy production can release non-GHG emissions into the environment, including VOCs, nitrogen oxides, sulfur oxides, particulate matter (PM10, PM2.5) and BTX compounds. These are typically released from exhaust emissions from engines, generators, gas compressors, pump engines and other production processes.
column14: Fossil fuels energy generation produces wastewater containing contaminants (i.e. acid or alkaline drainage, dust) during routine operations and accidents. Natural gas releases solid matter in suspension, organic components, and hydrocarbon traces (primarily because of engines). Coal power plants generate ashes with radioactive pollutants, and heavy metals that can affect the soil and water. Pollutants and effluents from coal power plants can lead to water contamination, land acidification, and deterioration of forests.
column16: Fossil fuels energy production can generate solid waste. The exact type of waste will vary but can include ash, slag, and particulates removed from flue gas.
column17: Fossil fuels energy production can require vast stretches of land for infrastructure, such as wells, pipelines, and access roads, as well as facilities for processing, waste storage, and waste disposal, which can lead to land degradation.
column18: In fossil fuels power plants, water is used for a variety of purposes, such as cooling systems and substations, demineralised water production, steam generation, industrial washing and sanitary use.
column20:

column3: Manufacture of wearing apparel
column4: Manufacture of knitted and crocheted apparel
column7: Manufacture of knitted and crocheted apparel can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of knitted and crocheted apparel can release carbon and other greenhouse gases from the machine level and disposal of material, contributing to air pollution.
column11: The manufacture of knitted and crocheted apparel can release non-greenhouse gas (non-GHG) emissions into the environment such as hydrogen sulphide, ammonia and phosphine are released from wet processes.
column14: Pollution may occur during knitted and crocheted apparel, because of using certain materials and substances. The process of dyeing requires an assortment of chemicals, such as bleaching agents, dyes, wetting agents, soap, softener, and salts to obtain the desired colours, which produce wastewater, causing contamination of water and soils.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Calcium carbide and acetylene are highly flammable compounds that are prone to explosion and combustion, increasing fire risk, thefore, a large amount of area may be required.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, dyeing and finishing, washing and cleaning textiles. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of coke and refined petroleum products
column7: Manufacture of refined petroleum products can cause disturbances like thermal and  noise  pollution from oil refineries. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations such disrupting marine ecosystems.
column9: Manufacturing of refined petroleum products can release greenhouse gases emissions (e.g. methane) from manufacturing processes , which can contributie atmospheric conditions.
column11: Chemical emissions of sulphur and nitrogen oxides during the manufacture of refined petroleum products can return to the environment as acid rain, negatively impacting natural resources. Other air pollutants from oil and gas refineries include benzene, toluene, ethylbenzene, xylene, carbon monoxide and particulate matter.
column14: Manufacture of refined petroleum products can result in spills and leaks from refineries, increasing the toxicity in soil and water. Waste from refineries can be disposed of through burial in onsite reserve pits, resulting in hazardous chemicals to spread to the surrounding environment. Contaminants such as aromatic hydrocarbons could enter waterways (both underground and surface), polluting vegetation, and resulting in habitat changes, affecting the diversity and abundance of fish and other wildlife.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as metal catalysts, wastewater, and tank bottom sludges from crude product storage tanks. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing of refined petroleum products uses larger volumes of water for a variety of processes such as in upstream processing (desalters, circulation pumps and coolants). Additionally large volumes of water are used for cooling purposes.

column3: Manufacture of paper and paper products
column4: Manufacture of paper and paper products
column7: Manufacture of paper and paper products can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery  and vehicles and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of paper and paper products can release greenhouse gases emissions through the use of fuel and energy during the forestry, pulping, and manufacturing stages of paper production, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Pulp mills heavily pollute air, water, and land, releasing over 100 million kg of pollutants annually.
column14: Manufacture of paper and paper products contribute to water and land pollution, through pulp mills. Pulp and paper is among the largest industrial polluter to air, water, and land in some countries, and the industry releases well over 100 million kg of toxic pollution each year.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include sludge which can be toxic dependent on the raw materials. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Pulp mills use large volumes of water for soaking pulp before producing paper. Water recycling systems can be put in place to reduce the severity of this impact on local water resources. However, this is not yet a common practice across the industry.

column3: Fishing and aquaculture
column7: Aquaculture operations can cause disturbances like light pollution due to artificial light at night used for surveillance. These can disrupt or negatively affect marine and freshwater species due to the lighting up of the water column from the surface to the seabed.
column8: Creation of ponds or reservoirs to enable aquaculture can result in the conversion of freshwater ecosystems into aquaculture farms (e.g. conversion of wetlands, deforestation of mangrove forests) and modification of hydrological patterns on regional ecosystems.
column9: Aquaculture can release greenhouse gas emissions through use of fertilizers, microbial nitrification and denitrification of nitrogenous compounds in the aquatic system. Some aquaculture activities also use on-site energy generators, which release greenhouse gas emissions.
column10: Creation of ponds or reservoirs to enable aquaculture requires use of marine ecosystems including seabeds. Marine aquaculture can affect hydrological features (currents) and sedimentation characteristics resulting in impact further away from the aquaculture activities.
column11: N/A
column12: It has been estimated that, for each million of shrimp postlarvae farmed, four to seven millions of other organisms are killed by trapping in the nets of farms inlet. Aquaculture has also contributed to fisheries collapse, overfishing and depletion of stock, and species declining. The loss of herbivorous and predatory fish species has reduced total fish biomass and altered the taxonomic composition of the fish community.
column14: Aquaculture activities often require treatment of soil using lime and other chemicals, which can also leach to other areas within the ecosystem or watershed. Aquaculture also tends to use a wide range of fertilizers, pharmaceuticals, including hormones, steroids, antibiotics, and parasiticides to improve productivity, which have been found in surface waters, and groundwaters. These chemicals can cause imbalances in the different ecosystems, including the reduction of water oxygen levels.
column15: Aquaculture can release substantial quantities of nutrient pollutants into adjacent soils and water bodies (e.g. through nonconsumed aquaculture feed, and, decomposition of dead organisms). Aquaculture production can also cause salt water intrusion into soil, which can exasperate nutrient pollution. For example, soil near some former aquaculture sites was found to be hypersaline, acid and eroded for long periods.
column16: Aquaculture activities generate solid waste. In respect to waste generation, approximately 3 tonnes of freshwater fish can be compared to a community of around 240 inhabitants. While most waste from aquaculture farms is collected by waste collection services, some can be improperly disposed of or used as fertiliser.
column17: Creation of ponds or reservoirs to enable land-based aquaculture can require use of large areas of land.
column18: Aquaculture accounts for about 15% of global freshwater use. Water is used in aquaculture for a variety of purposes, including filling and maintaining ponds and tanks, cooling water used in processing, diluting waste products, and washing equipment.
column19: Accidental release of fish into water bodies may result in introduction of invasive species.This leads to displacement of native species, competition for space and food, and spread of pathogens. Aquaculture can also increase the spread of pests that affect farmed fish and are transferred to wild fish.

column3: Manufacture of food products
column7: Manufacture of other food products can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of other food products can release greenhouse gases through energy used for machinery operation, dust extraction, ventilation, lighting and production of compressed air, contributing to air pollution.
column11: The manufacture of food products such as bakery products may result in air emissions of concern as volatile organic compounds (VOCs) such as ethanol from yeast metabolism. Ammonium carbonate (used as a leavening agent) may also be released and it can be toxic if inhaled at high concentrations.
column14: The manufacture of food products may generate spillages from products that if discharged without treatment will potentially pollute soils. Wastewater arising from cleaning and spillages will contain high quantities of organic matter and other material which if discharged without treatment will potentially pollute watercourses.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include spoiled raw materials, spillages, dough, non-conforming product, packaging wastes and sludge from wastewater treatment. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes in food and beverages use water as base ingredients but also for a variety of other purposes such as cleaning equipment, mixing ingredients, carbonation and packaging.

column3: Manufacture of food products
column7: Manufacture of dairy products can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of dairy products can release greenhouse gases emissions from manufacturing processes, contributing to air pollution.
column11: In dairy processes, gases primarily result from energy requirements, including CO, NOx, SO2, and ammonia (NH3) volatilization. NH3 emissions can occur due to leakage and stripping of idle chilling machines.
column12: Lactic acid bacteria commonly found in dairy products include strains of Streptococcus, Lactococcus, Lactobacilli, Bifidobacteria, Enterococcus, and Pediococci. Within these species there are numerous strain types which can be used in fermentation processes to give specific acidification and flavor profiles to the final product.
column14: Manufacture of dairy products may contain feed concentrates such as copper (Cu), zinc (Zn) and cadmium (Cd) which accumulate in the soil and vet medicines persist in dung, affecting fauna [1]. The impact of manufacture of dairy products in terms of toxic water pollutants may derive from pesticides [1] as these can contain toxic heavy metals [6].
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include spoiled raw materials, spillages, packaging materials and sludge from wastewater treatment. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Water is an essential element for dairy products: 85-90 % of milk is made of water. Water is also key to assure safe high-quality production of dairy products, as it is used in the dairy plants for heating, cooling, washing, and cleaning.

column3: Manufacture of food products
column4: Manufacture of grain mill products, starches and starch products
column7: Manufacture of grain mill products, starches and starch products can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of vehcles and  machinery e.g.  hammer mills, grinders, ventilation and banging equipment [3]  and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of grain mill products, starches and starch products can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy used for milling process, machinery operation, lighting and production of compressed air, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Grain mills may present a significant source of air pollution both on-site and in the surrounding locality. Release of dust to the atmosphere from storage handling or processing of grain products may generate a health risk to employees or a local nuisance.
column14: Sources of pollution derived from the manufacture of grain products include chemical cleaning materials, high alkalinity, solvent and oils used in equipment operation and cleaning materials. These may present a significant risk of pollution if allowed to be deposited on land. Additionally, major sources of wastewater of grain mills may present a significant risk of pollution if allowed to enter a river without treatment.
column16: Manufacturing processes can lead to creation of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include spoiled raw materials, spillages, non-conforming product, packaging wastes and sludge from wastewater treatment. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Water is used in the milling process, namely to reduce powdering which darkens the flour during the milling process. Most modern flour mills, for example, have automatic moisture measuring devices which control the water addition system to achieve consistent moisture across the batch.

column3: Food and beverage service activities
column7: Beverage serving activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of catering equipment and facilities (e.g., canteens and cafeterias and noise from customers). This can disrupt or negatively affect local species populations.
column8: Beverage serving activities can use large areas of freshwater ecosystems, which can lead to sedimentation, removal of vegetation and/or modification of surface and subterranean water flows, resulting in drying or flooding and river diversion and canalisation.
column9: Beverage serving activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Beverage serving activities emit non-greenhouse gases through gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations from, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment.
column14: Beverage serving activities generates large quantities of waste and wastewater which can include toxic pollutants to soil and water respectively.
column15: Beverage serving activities can release organic waste and waste water in case these are not disposed of properly. This can emit nutrient pollutants (e.g. nitrogen and phosphorus) into soil and water.
column16: Solid waste from beverage serving activities include leftover food and beverages, waste from bathroom facilities and other non-recyclables, which also contribute to pollution.
column17: Beverage and food serving premises occupy land.
column18: Retail buildings require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies (e.g. server farms associated with cloud facilities).

column3: Food and beverage service activities
column4: Event catering and other food service activities
column7: Event catering and other food service activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of catering equipment and facilities  (e.g., canteens and cafeterias and noise from customers). This can disrupt or negatively affect local species populations.
column8: Event catering and other food service activities can use large areas of freshwater ecosystems, which can lead to sedimentation, removal of vegetation and/or modification of surface and subterranean water flows, resulting in drying or flooding and river diversion and canalisation.
column9: Event catering and other food service activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Event catering and other food service activities emit non-greenhouse gases through gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations from, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment.
column14: Event catering and other food service activities generates large quantities of waste and wastewater which can include toxic pollutants to soil and water respectively.
column15: Event catering and other food service activities can release organic waste and waste water in case these are not disposed of properly. This can emit nutrient pollutants (e.g. nitrogen and phosphorus) into soil and water.
column16: Solid waste from event catering and other food service activities include leftover food and beverages, waste from bathroom facilities and other non-recyclables, which also contribute to pollution.
column17: Event caterers occupy land for a specified time period.
column18: Event catering and other food service activities use water for a variety of purposes, including food preparation, cleaning, sanitizing, laundry and wastewater treatment.

column4: Restaurants and mobile food service activities
column7: Restaurants and mobile food service activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of equipment and noise from customers. This can disrupt or negatively affect local species populations.
column8: Restaurants and mobile food service activities can use large areas of freshwater ecosystems, which can lead to sedimentation, removal of vegetation and/or modification of surface and subterranean water flows, resulting in drying or flooding and river diversion and canalisation.

column11: Restaurants and mobile food service activities emit non-greenhouse gases through gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations from, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment.
column14: Restaurants and mobile food service activities generates large quantities of waste and wastewater which can include toxic pollutants to soil and water respectively.
column15: Restaurants and mobile food service activities can release organic waste and waste water in case these are not disposed of properly. This can emit nutrient pollutants (e.g. nitrogen and phosphorus) into soil and water.

column3: Manufacture of food products
column4: Processing and preserving of fruit and vegetables
column5: Processing and preserving of fruit and vegetables
column7: Processing and preserving of fruit and vegetables can cause disturbances like noise, light and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery, lighting in production areas and odour from food waste. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Processing and preserving of fruit and vegetables can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy used in processing steps (e.g. peeling, cutting, slicing, milling, boiling, cooking and packing), contributing to air pollution.
column11: Processing and preserving fruit and vegetables can release non-greenhouse gas (non-GHG) emissions from chemical disinfectants used in food washing and processing facilities.
column12: Microbial processing of fruit and vegetable waste into essential enzymes and organic acids (e.g. citric and lactic acid).
column14: N/A
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include seeds, peelings, leaves, stems and pulp waste from processing and waste from spoilage of fruit and vegetables. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Water is used in a variety of steps in the processing and preserving process, including washing, grading cutting blanching peeling canning and freezing.

column3: Forestry and logging
column7: Some silviculture and forestry activities (e.g. thinning forests or transplanting trees) can cause disturbances such as noise pollution, generating intense noise for periods of days to weeks in a relatively small area. This can disrupt species populations, for example leading some species to temporarily abandon the area.
column9: ND
column11: Use of fertilisers and pesticides in managed forests can release non-GHG air pollutants.
column14: In managed forests, herbicides and pesticides are used to increase productivity, which can release toxic soil and water pollutants into surrounding soil and waterways.
column15: In managed forests, nitrate and phosphorus are used to address nutrient deficient deficiencies to increase forest productivity. They can lead to build up of nutrient pollutants in the area and leakage of the pollutants to surrounding areas and water bodies through nutrient runoff.
column16: Silviculture generates solid waste. The majority of this waste is damaged residuals, abandoned logs, stumps, tops and branches. But it can also be material and machinery used in silviculture activities. If improperly disposed of, this can lead to habitat degradation and air pollution.
column17: Silviculture requires large areas of land. It can also contribute to the degradation of land in their proximity of the managed forests (e.g. managed forests do no provide the same level of landslide prevention as natural forests).
column18: Silviculture and other forestry activities use a significant amount of water for planting trees, irrigating forests, and controlling pests.
column19: Silviculture activities often involve introduction of new tree or non-tree species to increase productivity, which can become or accidentally lead to the spreading of invasive species. Silviculture activities can also contribute to spread of invasive forest species by improper timber waste disposal and accidental spread of seeds and plants on machinery or worker's uniforms. Unsuitable forest management practices can also weaken native forests, reducing their capacity to control spread of new species.

column3: Manufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork, except furniture; manufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials
column4: Manufacture of products of wood, cork, straw and plaiting materials
column7: Manufacture of products of wood, cork, straw and plaiting materials can cause disturbances like noise, odour and light pollution due to the operation of machinery, processes such as gluing and finishing and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of products of wood, cork, straw and plaiting materials can release greenhouse gases emissions during the transportation of timber from forest to sawmills and manufacturing facilities, accounting for almost half of the total GHG emissions.
column11: Manufacturing of woods products may release emissions of nitrogenous compounds to both air and water, causing environmental pollution.
column14: Manufacture of products of wood, cork, straw and plaiting materials may release emissions of nitrogenous compounds to both air and water, causing environmental pollution. For instance, different types of chemicals are used in the process, especially in preservative treatment, adhesive application and coating of final products. For example, disposal of timber from demolition building sites still retaining high levels of preservatives, which can release soil pollutants.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include synthetic materials. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Disposal materials can occupy large areas of land through landfill sites and create the need for new waste disposal sites.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork, except furniture; manufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials
column7: Sawmilling and planing of wood can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery  that can disrupt or negatively affect species in surrounding areas.
column9: Sawmilling and planing of wood can release greenhouse gases emissions through the use of heavy machinery, charcoal making and saw dust leachate at sites, contributing to air pollution.
column11: The use of heavy machinery in the sawmilling industry, as well as onsite transportation that leads to diesel fuel burning, generates emissions of non-GHG, including NOx, N2O, SO2 and CO. These gases' impacts include acidification, eutrophication and photo-oxidant formation.
column14: The use of heavy machinery, charcoal production, and saw dust in sawmilling and planing of wood leachates at sites, increasing the levels of soil and water pollution.
column16: Forestry and wood processing generates solid waste, including damaged residuals, abandoned logs, stumps, tops and branches. This can lead to incineration and adverse environmental impacts such as air pollution.
column17: Clear cutting for forestry plantations can cause large scale biodiversity loss, alter habitats and increase soil degradation. Forest management or removal and replacement with exotics may deprive some animals of food and shelter, and may attract and harbour pests. Logging and leftover ground vegetation may increase fire risk. Compaction, exposure, and damage due to forestry activities may alter soil characteristics and vegetation types, making them more vulnerable to erosion and landslides.
column18: Water is used in a variety of steps in the sawmilling and planning process, including cooling saw blades, flushing sawdust and cleaning wood.

column3: Other manufacturing
column7: Manufacture of games and toys can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of games and toys can release greenhouse gases emissions during manufacturing processes, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Manufacturing processes of game and toy products can lead to gaseous emissions. Other forms of pollution may occur as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals.
column14: Manufacture of games and toys lead to non-product outputs, as well as pollution occuring as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals. All these chemical liquids affect soil and water. Microplastic pollution in particular is a growing threat in the world's oceans.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Other manufacturing
column7: Manufacture of sports goods can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of sports goods can release emissions of GHG during the manufacture process, in sports apparel and footwear manufacturing—e.g., injection moulding, used in manufacturing of outsoles and heels, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Manufacturing processes can release non-GHG emissions into the environment, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs). Pollution may occur as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals.
column14: Manufacture of sports goods release chemicals during the processing of raw materials, fibre production and clothing production, which can lead to soil and water pollution.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Land transport and transport via pipelines
column7: Other land transport can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to vehicles causing noise and dust pollution that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column9: Other land transport activities can release greenhouse gas emissions from fuels, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Land transport activities can result in air pollution due to the use of fuels and chemicals during distribution, leading to emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Additionally, asphalt road surfaces may emit VOCs when exposed to high levels of sunlight and heat.
column14: Toxic soil and water pollutants  (e.g. heavy metals such as Pb, Cu, Cr, Fe, Ni, Zn) may be leached into the environment in land transport. Runoff from roads can increase pollution in soils, wetlands and streams unless the runoff is treated. Additionally, water pollution can occur from fuels and chemicals used during distribution.
column15: Water and soil pollutants, including phosphorus and nitrogen, may leak from cargo in case of accidents.
column16: Other land transport generates solid waste. While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed (e.g. litter at stations and from transport vehicles by passengers).
column17: Other land transport uses significant areas of land for road, railway and other infrastructure. The transport infrastructure can cause a  barrier to animal movement causing decreased landscape connectivity,  cut through migratory corridors and cause collisions with wildlife.
column18: Other land transport uses water for a variety of purposes, e.g. cleaning, maintenance or firefighting.
column19: Some other land transport activities (e.g. long distance buses) may unintentionally introduce non-native invasive species either by attachment to vehicles or through other traffic-related dispersal mechanisms. e.g. invasive plants along road corridors.

column3: Manufacture of wearing apparel
column7: Manufacture of articles of fur can cause disturbances like noise, and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Manufacturing of articles of fur can be release greenhouse gases emissions from the machine level, transport, production, and disposal of material, tools, and consumable contributing to air pollution.
column11: Manufacture of articles of fur can release non-GHG emissions into the environment, including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs). Pollution may occur as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals.
column14: Manufacture of articles of fur lead to non-product outputs, as well as pollution occuring as a result of using certain materials and substances such as acids, solvents, compressed gases, colourants, binders, solders, paints, oils and other chemicals. All these chemical liquids affect soil and water.
column16: Manufacturing production processes lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary but these can include non-product outputs such as fur offcuts and toxic substances. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation or land contamination.
column17: Manufacturing facilities occupy land.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
