column3: Land transport and transport via pipelines
column7: Transport via pipeline can cause disturbances like noise pollution. The flow noise in pipelines may vary by product transported and flow velocity. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation (e.g. in the subterranean ecosystems where the pipelines are located).
column8: Pipelines can be installed in freshwater areas.
column9: Transport via pipeline can release greenhouse gases emissions from on-site power generators used to power pipeline pumps. Some gases and liquids transported through pipelines can also release greenhouse gases if they are leaked due to accidents or through ventilation.
column10: Pipelines can be installed on seabeds. Besides the area occupied by the pipelines and associated infrastructure, the pipelines can also affect the seabed habitats by releasing into the water biocides that are used to prevent corrosion of the pipes.
column11: Hazardous air pollutants (HAPs) are released by pipelines (e.g. transporting natural gas) during standard operation or as fugitive emissions from leakages, venting, and flaring. Additional non-GHG air pollutants can be released in case of accidents.
column14: Toxic soil and water pollutants are released by pipelines (e.g. transporting natural gas) during standard operation or as fugitive emissions from leakages, venting, and flaring. Additional toxic pollutants can be released in case of accidents.
column15: Nitrogen can be used for purging of pipelines, during which some emissions to soil and water can occur.
column16: Transport via pipeline can produce a marginal amount of waste.
column17: Transport via pipeline requires occupation of significant areas by the pipelines as well as associated infrastructure such as pumping stations. 5 19
column18: Transport of some substances via pipeline requires water (e.g. water emulsions for transportation of oil).

column3: Land transport and transport via pipelines
column7: Transport via railway can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of trains e.g. from wheel contact and aerodynamic noise. This can can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column9: Transport via railways can release greenhouse gases emissions (e.g. carbon dioxide, hydrofluorocarbons, and other indirect gases), contributing to air pollution.
column11: Transport via railways emits non-GHG air pollutants. These include carbon monoxide (CO), sulphur dioxide (SO2), nitrogen oxides (NOx), hydrocarbons, particulate matter, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). Diesel powered trains tends to emit more non-GHG air pollutants than electric trains.
column14: Transport via railways can emit toxic soil and water pollutants through accidental release of transported substances and in case of accidents.
column15: Transport via railways can cause nutrient pollution through use of organic herbicides for vegetation control in railtrack areas, discharge of human waste and accidental release of waste and other organic substances from the train.
column16: Transport by railways generates solid waste. While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed (e.g. glass, plastic and organic waste from passenger trains).
column17: Transport via railways uses significant areas of land for rail tracks and other infrastructure. Land occupation from rail transportation may cause collisions with wildlife.10
column18: Transport via railways uses water for a variety of purposes, including cooling, cleaning, potential snow removal and firefighting.
column19: Railways represent potential corridors along which alien invasive species may spread. These species may be transferred to new areas by attachment to trains or through accidental spillage of transported goods.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains
column7: Manufacture of gas; distribution of gaseous fuels through mains can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to seismic drilling and need for adequate lighting. This can disrupt or negatively affect species' populations and lead to habitat fragmentation or disruption of species' migration routes.
column8: Mains distribution systems can use large areas of freshwater ecosystems, altering their extent and hydrological characteristics.
column9: Manufacturing of gas can release greenhouse gases through production processes that require creating high pressure to separate elements. This contributes to atmospheric pollution.
column11: Accidental spillages or losses of products can have negative chemical effects on surrounding habitats, ecosystems and the atmosphere.
column14: Spills and leaks from storage sites or mains from the manufacturing of gas, can increase toxicity in terrestrial areas and water bodies.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Mains distribution lines use land, which can lead to erosion and disrupt terrestrial ecosystems.
column18: Manufacture of gas and its distribution require water for operations and distribution via mains lines. These processes typically require large amounts of water from localised areas, which can deplete water reserves. When this coincides with adverse weather conditions this can significantly increase the risk of drought.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Geothermal energy production can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery, and facilities that are lightened at night. This can disrupt or negatively affect species such as leading to displacement of populations.
column9: Geothermal power production can release greenhouse gases, including CO2 (estimated at between 4-740 g CO2/kWh), contributing to air pollution.
column11: Geothermal energy production can lead to the emission of non-GHG air pollutants into the environment, including sulfur oxides.
column14: Geothermal power production releases several types of pollutants into the environment, including minerals and heavy metals, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Geothermal energy production may release solid waste from different stages of the process (e.g. drill cuttings, scale from cooling water, scale from maintenance, wastewater, hazardous solid waste from maintenance of machines and heavy equipment).
column17: Geothermal power plants occupy land.
column18: Geothermal power plants have a high water footprint, which can lead to higher rates of local water abstraction, particularly when water is extracted directly from nearby water bodies. Added to this high water consumption, mechanisms used to extract/return water mean some geothermal power plants can have negative impacts on populations of local freshwater species. Intensive extraction or injection of fluids or steam can result in local geological changes, including landslides and erosion.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Hydropower energy production can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery and underground water discharges. Light pollution can also occur due to facilities that are lightened at night. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Hydropower energy production can lead to a large increase in freshwater habitat upstream, and a decrease in freshwater habitat downstream. Alteration of sediment and water flow by hydropower stations can result in an increased likelihood of erosion.
column9: Hydropower energy production can release low levels of greenhouse gases from water reservoirs, contributing to air pollution.
column11: N/A
column14: ND
column16: Hydropower energy production may release solid waste from different stages of the process (i.e., when basins are full of sediments) that can potentially affect fauna.
column17: Hydropower projects can impact on terrestrial ecosystems and their components (plants and animals) through displacement and/or mortality (particularly for plants).
column18: Some hydropower projects may lead to diversion of water, which can result in unsustainable water abstraction. This can affect the amount of water available within a watershed and in some cases can result in increased likelihood of drought on a local basis.

column3: Libraries, archives, museums and other cultural activities
column4: Libraries, archives, museums and other cultural activities
column7: Libraries, archives, museums, and other cultural activities can cause disturbances like noise pollution or physical disturbance due to visitor or visitor transport to nature reserves or historical sites This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Cultural activities around world heritage sites can take place on or near freshwater ecosystems.
column9: Libraries, archives, museums and other cultural activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for the heating, cooling and lighting buildings, for heating glasshouses and animal enclosures, from fossil fuels used by vehicles in operations around sites, and from transportation to different sites.
column10: Seabed area covered by marine protected areas can experience some risk from diving activities in marine protected areas by tourists.
column11: Gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment, collectively contribute to environmental pollution, emitting non-greenhouse gases.
column14: Potential emissions of nutrient soil pollutants by incorrect management of animal waste from zoological gardens. Libraries and library archives using facilities and buildings produce waste and discharges that can be emitted into the surrounding environment, affecting soil and water bodies.
column15: Other cultural activities such as zoological gardens could emit nutrient soil pollutants by incorrect management of animal waste.
column16: Libraries, museums and other buildings associated with service provision, as well as visitors, create solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Improper disposal of this waste can contribute to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Land area occupied by library buildings and museums, gardens, monuments or historical sites. Terrestrial protected areas e.g. nature reserves, can experience some adverse impacts from visitors e.g. vegetation trampling, soil erosion, disturbance to wildlife.
column18: Significant amounts of water can be used in museums and gardens e.g. from gardens/grounds maintenance to toilet facilities for visitors and cleaning. Water is also used in botanical and zoological gardens e.g. for plant watering, water for animals, in marine enclosures and aquariums.
column19: Cultural tourism can lead to the accidental introduction of invasive species e.g. introduction of ornamental plants in lodges and staff villages at or near World Heritage Sites

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply

column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Ocean energy production can cause significant physical disturbances like noise pollution due to marine traffic, power structures, turbines, generators, exploration, sonar and offshore activities. There may also be light pollution and electromagnetic fields from ocean facilities. This can disrupt or negatively affect marine species, causing injury, behavioural changes and obstructing migratory routes.
column9: Ocean energy production can release low levels of greenhouse gases during routine operations, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Wave energy collectors can occupy areas of the seabed disturbing benthic species and habitats; they can also alter the water column and seabed habitats locally and over large distances changing hydrological and geomorphological features and consequent biodiversity.
column11: Non-GHG air pollutants may arise from vessels employed to service, maintain and monitor facilities.
column14: Ocean energy production can cause water pollution from paint, which is used to inhibit marine growth and biofouling.
column16: Ocean energy production may produce a marginal amount of waste.
column17: Land may be occupied for the landing structures from offshore facilities.
column18: Ocean energy production uses water to generate power. Some ocean energy technologies, such as wave and tidal power, use very little water, while others, such as ocean thermal energy conversion (OTEC), use large volumes of water.

column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Nuclear power production can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and vehicles, and the need for adequate lighting during routine operation. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: When water is used for cooling thermal power stations, water withdrawal mechanisms from freshwater sources can affect areas of freshwater ecosystems and can harm or kill aquatic species. Nuclear power plants can occupy freshwater ecosystems.
column9: Nuclear power plants can release greenhouse gases (e.g. carbon dioxide, nitrous oxide, methane) and through the processing of uranium. Substantial sulphur hexafluoride can also be released from electric/nuclear power transmission and distribution. Combustion of fossil fuels only occurs when emergency systems are activated, to ensure cooling of the reactors.
column11: Nuclear power plants can emit gases (e.g. carbon monoxide) and radioactive substances (e.g. CH14 and H3).
column14: Nuclear power plants can emit radioactive substances (e.g., CH14 and H3), which could pollute vegetation and lead to decreases in soil productivity. Soil and groundwater quality have been affected by a legacy of leaks of radioactivity from historical operations.
column16: Nuclear power stations produce various types of solid waste, most importantly hazardous nuclear waste, which requires careful treatment and storage. Decommissionning of nuclear power plants produces important quantities of both radioactive and conventional solid waste. Additional forms of solid waste include resins, sludges and filter media, among others.
column17: The land use of a nuclear-power plant itself is higher than that of a coalfired plant because it adds an exclusion area and a barrier space reserved for a possible accident.
column18: Nuclear power plants and thermal plants have substantial water requirements for their routine operating processes (e.g. production of steam and cooling processes). Cooling systems include towers, once-through systems or ponds. Withdrawals can be significant but volumes and returned fractions depend on the design of the cooling systems. 1kWh of output requires the withdrawal of up to 200 litres of water taken from and returned to the environment after a cycle.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Solar energy production can generate noise from inverters, transformers, cooling fans and trackers.  Light pollution can also occur due to facilities that are lightened at night. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: ND
column11: N/A
column14: Potentially toxic or hazardous substances are sometimes used when constructing solar thermal farms, which can result in pollution of soil and water bodies on a local basis.
column16: Solar energy farms (photovoltaic and solar thermal) generate solid waste. The exact form of waste will vary but includes discarded solar panels, which contain toxic substances such as crystalline silicon. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as habitat degradation and soil pollution.
column17: Solar energy farms (photovoltaic and solar thermal) use land, which modifies terrestrial ecosystems. The footprint of a typical solar farm is estimated at 22.5-25.9 m2/GWh. Solar farms often use a fence or other barrier along their perimeter, which can affect species' movement and can fragment habitats. Soil compaction may occur from solar farm installation, which can lead to increased erosion and runoff.
column18: The production of solar energy can use water, but the amount of water used varies depending on the type of solar energy system. PV solar panels do not use water directly other than in manufacturing, whereas CSP systems use water to generate steam.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column7: N/A
column8: Steam and air conditioning supply including water abstraction for the distribution of water can lead to land subsidence, which can impact on freshwater ecosystems.
column9: Steam and air conditioning supply can release greenhouse gases stemming from the operation of water treatment plants and systems and the related energy use, contributing to air pollution. Air conditioning uses cooling fluids that release greenhouse gases (PFC, SF6, and, HFC) due to leaks or maintenance operations.
column11: The solid waste created by water treatment is composed of volatile solids (as much as 60% to 80%), which can lead to the emissions of non-GHG air pollutants if improperly disposed of or incinerated without air pollution control.
column14: Accidental discharges of wastewater into the terrestrial environment can result in well contamination and spread of odours.
column16: Steam and air conditioning supply can produce a marginal amount of waste.
column17: ND
column18: Steam and air conditioning supply uses water in multiple ways such as cooling, humidification, steam generation and cleaning. It is estimated that the average steam and AC system uses about 10,000 gallons of water per year. Water abstraction for distribution to end users (individuals or businesses) directly affects freshwater sources (e.g., aquifers and water bodies). This can impact on sensitive habitats and ecosystems if abstraction levels exceed a sustainable threshold (location dependent).

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Wind energy production can cause disturbances like noise pollution from wind turbines. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations in localised areas such as altering migration patterns.
column9: N/A
column10: Construction and the footprint of offshore wind farms lead to changes in hydological features (current patterns) and seabed morphology, and ultimately habitat modification in the marine environment.
column11: N/A
column14: Maintenance activities of wind energy production can cause soil and water pollution from oil or other waste products, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Wind energy production can generate large volumes of solid waste. The exact type of waste varies but includes discarded composite turbine blades once at the end of their lifespan. These are challenging to recycle and can lead to habitat degradation if inappropriately disposed of.
column17: Construction of onshore wind farms leads to modification of terrestrial ecosystems.
column18: Wind energy production does not directly use water to generate electricity. However, it may be used for cooling bearings and other components as required.

column3: Manufacture of basic metals
column7: Casting of metals can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery. This can negatively affect species populations and lead to large-scale species migrations. There may also be a risk of flying particles, sparks and optical radiation.
column9: Casting of metals can release high levels of carbon and other greenhouse gases emissions from the machinery used in extraction, and from certain substances that self combust under oxidative and high sulphur conditions. Sulphur dioxide is emitted from waste/impurities, and a significant amount of carbon oxides are released during casting.
column11: Cyanide species used in leaching processes are susceptible to vaporisation, causing atmospheric release of cyanide (a toxic compound). Casting of metals produce emissions of chemicals and airborne pollutants. Harmful substances such as ammonia, acetone, phenol, formaldehyde, furfural, etc. can be released into the atmosphere, depending on the class of the binder.
column14: Tailings left from the casting of metals process affect soils due to high concentrations of heavy metals (i.e., metal oxides). Wastewaters arising from various process stages (i.e., treatment and leaching, purification, and electrolysis activities) are likely to contain soluble and insoluble metal compounds, oil, grease, etc. These toxic materials can leach and modify biogenic habitats and negatively impact species.
column15: Nitrogen and phosphorus can be used as additives in the process of casting of metals. Nitrogen and phosphorus can be emitted during the casting process.
column16: Large volumes of solid waste are produced during casting of metals including sand, aluminium used for molds and binders, hazardous and non-hazardous residues such as slag, spent refractory linings, cathode waste and smelter dust from abatement systems.
column17: Use of heavy machinery, explosives and flammable liquids in processing can lead to increase of non-natural fires at sites. Fire/explosions can result in widespread contamination and destruction, impacting surrounding land and communities. Additionally, land occupied by the manufacture facilities.
column18: Water consumption may be high in casting depending on the type of furnace used, the type of flue-gas cleaning and the casting method. Water is used for cooling, quenching operations and wet dedusting systems. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column2: Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities
column3: Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery
column7: Materials recovery processes can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas, that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Materials recovery can release greenhouse gas emissions from the use of machinery, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Emissions of non-greenhouse air pollutants can occur from the use of vehicles and machinery during materials recovery.
column14: Materials recovery such as mechanical processing of metal and non-metal waste and scraps, or chemical transformation processes may result in the emissions of toxic pollutants to soil and water.
column16: Materials recovery can produce a marginal amount of waste.
column17: Land may be occupied for materials recovery processes.
column18: Materials recovery processes use water for activities such as washing and sorting materials and cooling equipment.
column19: Invasive species can spread during the process of materials recovery when seeds, spores, or other propagules are inadvertently transported.

column3: Manufacture of basic metals
column4: Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals
column7: Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery. This can negatively affect species populations and lead to large-scale species migrations. There may also be a risk of flying particles, sparks and optical radiation.
column9: Manufacturing of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals can release nitrous oxide, carbon dioxide, and other indirect greenhouse gases from the operation of equipment, polluting the atmosphere.
column11: Carbon monoxide, sulphur dioxide, and fugitive dust are released from the operation of equipment, polluting the atmosphere.
column14: Manufacture of basic precious and other non-ferrous metals can dispose of toxic chemicals in landfills. These toxic materials can modify biogenic habitats and negatively impact habitats and species. Wastewaters arising from various manufacturing process stages are likely to contain soluble and insoluble metal compounds, oil, grease, heavy metals, etc. This is very destructive in wetlands that are highly sensitive to changes in pH.
column15: Nitrogen and phosphorus can be used as additives in the process of manufacture of metals. Nitrogen and phosphorus can be emitted during the manufacturing process.
column16: A range of hazardous and non-hazardous residues and wastes are produced during manufacture of basic metals including slag, spent refractory linings, waste from abatement systems, cathode waste, smelter dust, and sludge from wastewater treatment and leaching, purification and electrolysis activities.
column17: Use of heavy machinery, explosives and flammable liquids in processing can lead to increase of non-natural fires at sites. Fire/explosions can result in widespread contamination and destruction, impacting surrounding land and communities. Additionally, land occuppied by the manufacture facilities.
column18: Water is used for cooling and quenching operations and wet dedusting systems, and also used in flotation beneficiation, smelting, and electro-refining. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of basic pharmaceutical products and pharmaceutical preparations
column4: Manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemical and botanical products
column7: Manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemical and botanical products can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery and the need for adequate lighting in production areas that can disrupt or negatively affect species.
column9: Manufacturing of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemical and botanical products can release greenhouse gases emissions from the direct energy usage in the manufacturing facility, in which the global pharmaceutical industry is estimated to have emitted 52 MMt-CO2e in 2015.
column11: The manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemicals and botanical products  can release non-greenhouse gas (non-GHG) emissions into the environment including volatile organic compounds (VOCs), particulate matter (PM), and hazardous air pollutants (HAPs).
column14: Discharges from the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemical and botanical products have in many countries led to contamination of irrigated soils. Similarly, wastes and wastewater produced by the manufacturing process can contain pollutants that harm rivers, water sources, and wildlife (causing population changes and affect animal physiology).
column15: Manufacture of pharmaceuticals can release nutrient pollutants, such as phosphoric acid.
column16: Manufacturing processes create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: The primary use of land in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, medicinal chemicals and botanical products is for manufacturing plants and facilities, that can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat. fragmentation.
column18: Manufacturing processes require large volumes of water for processing materials, cleaning, rinsing, cooling and testing equipment. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.

column3: Manufacture of beverages
column5: Distilling, rectifying and blending of spirits
column7: ND
column9: Distilling, rectifying and blending of spirits can release greenhouse gases emissions such as CO2, nitrous oxide, and sulphur dioxide from production processes contributing to atmospheric pollution.
column11: Distilleries can emit air pollutants such as ethanol emissions from storing spirits in wooden barrels.
column14: Manufacture of beverages and the distilling process produces wastewater, pollutants and hazardous wastes (e.g. chemicals) that can have toxic effects on soil and water.
column15: Distillery wash water can contain substances such as nitrogen, phosphorus, calcium and sulphates.
column16: Recyclable and non-recyclable solid waste (e.g. packaging, spent grains and hops, yeast, diatomaceous earth, by-products from distilling), and hazardous waste (e.g. chemicals) can lead to increased environmental pollution.
column17: Distilleries buildings occupy land.
column18: Fermentation and distilling requires substantial volumes of water, leading to increased water abstraction. For example, it is estimated that 12 litres of water are required to distil 1 litre of whisky. In addition, the quality of local water is important to the distillation as it imparts it's own geographical influence over the quality and characteristics of the output.

column2: Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities
column3: Water collection, treatment and supply
column7: Water collection, treatment and supply can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of machinery in treatment plant and wastewater pumping stations, that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Water collection, treatment and supply can impact the geomorphology and hydrology of rivers, lakes and wells which can cause a negative impact on the environment.
column9: Water collection, treatment and supply can release greenhouse gas emissions due to its energy consumption, which can lead to air pollution.
column11: Water collection, treatment and supply can generate non-greenhouse gas emissions such as methane, and nitrous oxide, which can lead to air pollution.
column14: Water collection, treatment, and supply can involve methods and reagents that generate both solid and liquid wastes, which can lead to soil and water pollution.
column16: Water treatment can generate solid waste though the use of reagents. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts such as water pollution.
column17: Water collection, treatment and supply can require large areas of land for infrastructure facilities and operations for its treatment.
column18: Water collection, treatment and supply uses water through pumps, chemical treatment and other infrastructure. It is estimated that the average water utility uses about 10% of the water it collects for these purposes.

column3: Construction of buildings
column7: Construction of buildings can cause disturbances like noise, light, and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g., during excavation or transportation), that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Construction of buildings can occur on reclaimed land from freshwater systems. Adjacent to freshwater systems, it can lead to sedimentation near crossings of cultivated flood plains, removal of freshwater vegetation and/or modification of surface and subterranean water flows, resulting in drying or flooding and river diversion and canalisation to accommodate new infrastructure.
column9: Construction of buildings can release carbon dioxide and other indirect greenhouse gases from the use of heavy machinery, vehicular traffic and use of explosives; contributing to air pollution.
column10: Construction of buildings can occur on reclaimed land from marine systems.
column11: Construction of buildings can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.
column14: Construction of buildings may pollute soil and water sources due to waste disposal (e.g., wastewater, drainage, groundwater, drilling) and excavated material (debris/muck/dredged material). Spills of diesel, paints, solvents, and toxic chemicals during construction can also contribute to irreversible salinisation and acidification of certain soils (e.g., mangrove swamps).
column16: Construction processes can lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as cement, glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood and rubber.
column17: Construction can use large areas of land, which can result in habitat clearance, degradation and fragmentation, including along transportation corridors. Use of vehicles and heavy machinery in construction, including roads and railways, can lead to: 1) compaction of alluvial soils; 2) loss of topsoil, erosion and modification of surface relief in borrow zones; 3) excessive slope loading, causing downslope failure ; 4) altered slope drainage regimes.
column18: Construction requires large volumes of water for purposes such as mixing concrete, excavation, mudjacking, waterproofing and cooling. Excavation can lower the water table in surrounding areas, while embankments and structures can raise the water table by restricting flows. This can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can be unintentionally brought to a construction site on vehicles or workers, which can impact the ecology of the site and surrounding area.

column3: Civil engineering
column4: Construction of other civil engineering projects
column7: Construction of other civil engineering projects can cause disturbances like noise, light, and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g., during excavation or transportation), that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Construction activities, especially those involving the utilization of rivers and lakes, such as building bridges or dams, can lead to changes in the geomorphology of freshwater systems and their hydrology, as well as the clearance and degradation of freshwater habitats.
column9: Construction of other civil engineering projects using heavy machinery can release greenhouse gases emissions, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Construction activities such as building bridges, harbours and ports can lead to changes in the geomorphology of marine systems and their hydrology, as well as the clearance and degradation of marine habitats.
column11: Construction of other civil engineering projects can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.
column14: Construction of civil engineering projects can cause toxic water and soil pollution through spills of diesel, paints, solvents, and toxic chemicals. In some areas of the world, there are less stringent requirements for the disposal of toxic construction waste products, resulting in significant local environmental damage following a construction project.
column16: Construction production processes can lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as cement, glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber.
column17: Construction can use large areas of land, which can result in the clearing and degradation of habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas. Construction also may lead to flooding as hard surfaces reduce the land's capacity to absorb rain water. The use of vehicles and heavy machinery can cause soil compaction, which can impede root growth.
column18: Construction requires large volumes of water for purposes such as mixing concrete, excavation, mudjacking, waterproofing and cooling. Additionally, excavation can lower the water table in surrounding areas, while embankments and structures can raise the water table by restricting flow. This can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can be unintentionally brought to a construction site on vehicles or workers, which can impact the ecology of the site and surrounding area.

column3: Civil engineering
column7: Construction of roads and railways can cause disturbances like noise, light, and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g., during excavation or transportation), that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Road and tunnel construction can occur within freshwater systems, leading to reclamation of land, sedimentation near crossings of cultivated flood plains, removal of freshwater vegetation and modification of surface and subterranean water flows, resulting in drying or flooding and river diversion and canalisation to accommodate new infrastructure.
column9: Construction of roads and railways can release carbon dioxide and other indirect greenhouse gases from the use of heavy machinery, vehicular traffic and use of explosives; contributing to air pollution.
column10: Road and tunnel construction can occur within marine systems, leading to modification of surface and subterranean water flow.
column11: Construction of roads and railways can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.
column14: Construction of roads and railways may pollute soil and water sources due to waste disposal (e.g., wastewater, drainage, groundwater, drilling) and excavated material (debris/muck/dredged material). Spills of diesel, paints, solvents, and toxic chemicals during construction can also contribute to irreversible salinisation and acidification of certain soils (e.g., mangrove swamps).
column16: Construction production processes can lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as cement, glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber.
column17: Construction can use large areas of land, which can result in habitat clearance, degradation and fragmentation, including along transportation corridors. Use of vehicles and heavy machinery in construction, including roads and railways, can lead to: 1) compaction of alluvial soils; 2) loss of topsoil, erosion and modification of surface relief in borrow zones; 3) excessive slope loading, causing downslope failure ; 4) altered slope drainage regimes.
column18: Construction requires large volumes of water for purposes such as mixing concrete, excavation, mudjacking, waterproofing and cooling. Additionally, excavation can lower the water table in surrounding areas, while embankments and structures can raise the water table by restricting flow. This can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can be unintentionally brought to a construction site on vehicles or workers, which can impact the ecology of the site and surrounding area.

column3: Specialized construction activities
column7: Other specialized construction activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g., from pile driving), that can disrupt or negatively affect  species in surrounding areas.
column8: Specialized construction activities can result in the reclamation of land from freshwater systems. Activities could result in the clearing and degradation of freshwater habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas.
column9: Other specialized construction activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from the use of heavy machinery; contributing to air pollution.
column10: Specialized construction activities such as building bridges, harbours and ports can lead to changes in the geomorphology of marine systems and their hydrology, as well as the clearance and degradation of marine habitats.
column11: Other specialized construction activities can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.
column14: Specialized construction activities can cause toxic water and soil pollution through spills of diesel, paints, solvents, and toxic chemicals. In some areas of the world, there are less stringent requirements for the disposal of toxic construction waste products, resulting in significant local environmental damage following a construction project.
column16: Specialized construction activities can lead to the creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as cement, glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber.
column17: Specialized construction activities can use large areas of land, which can result in the clearing and degradation of habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas. Construction may lead to flooding as hard surfaces reduce the land's capacity to absorb rain water. The use of vehicles and heavy machinery can cause soil compaction, which can impede root growth.
column18: Construction requires large volumes of water for purposes such as mixing concrete, excavation, mudjacking, waterproofing and cooling. Additionally, excavation can lower the water table in surrounding areas, while embankments and structures can raise the water table by restricting flow. This can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can be unintentionally brought to a construction site on vehicles or workers, which can impact the ecology of the site and surrounding area.

column3: Civil engineering
column7: Construction of utility projects can cause disturbances like noise, light, and odour pollution due to the operation of machinery (e.g., during excavation or transportation) that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Construction of utility projects like canals, reservoirs, sewage disposal plants and pumping stations can result in large changes to the geomorphology and hydrology of freshwater ecosystems. Impacts include the clearing and degradation of habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas.
column9: Construction of utility projects using heavy machinery can release greenhouse gases emissions; contributing to air pollution.
column10: Construction of utility projects like pipelines can result in changes to the geomorphology and hydrology of marine ecosystems. Impacts include the clearing and degradation of habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas.
column11: Construction of utility projects can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.
column14: Construction of utility projects can cause toxic water and soil pollution through spills of diesel, paints, solvents, and toxic chemicals. In some areas of the world, there are less stringent requirements for the disposal of toxic construction waste products, resulting in significant local environmental damage following a construction project.
column16: Construction of utility projects can lead to creation of large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as cement, glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber.
column17: Construction of utility projects can use large areas of land, which can result in the clearing and degradation of habitats, leading to loss of biodiversity and natural capital on the construction sites and surrounding areas. Construction may lead to flooding as hard surfaces reduce the land's capacity to absorb rain water. The use of vehicles and heavy machinery can cause soil compaction, which can impede root growth. Power lines contribute to habitat fragmentation and sub-stations have a local land use footprint.
column18: Construction requires large volumes of water for purposes such as mixing concrete, excavation, mudjacking, waterproofing and cooling. Additionally, excavation can lower the water table in surrounding areas, while embankments and structures can raise the water table by restricting flow. This can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can be unintentionally brought to a construction site on vehicles or workers, which can impact the ecology of the site and surrounding area.

column11: Demolition and site preparation activities can generate non-GHG emissions such as particulate matter (PM), volatile organic compounds (VOCs) from materials, and nitrogen oxides (NOx) from machinery and vehicles.

column2: Wholesale and retail trade; repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles
column3: Wholesale and retail trade and repair of motor vehicles and motorcycles
column4: Sale of motor vehicle parts and accessories
column7: Sale of motor vehicle parts and accessories can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to in vehicles used in warehouses to move and test large quantities of motor vehicle parts and accessories.
column9: Sale of motor vehicle parts and accessories can release CO2 and other indirect GHGs from fuels and chemicals used during distribution, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Sale of motor vehicle parts and accessories can result in air pollution due to the use of fuels and chemicals during distribution, leading to emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Harmful and polluting substances (potentially toxic heavy metals such as Pb, Cu, Cr, Fe, Ni, Zn) may be leached into the environment in wholesale trade. Runoff from roads can increase pollution in soils, wetlands and streams unless the runoff is treated. Additionally, water pollution can occur from fuels and chemicals used during distribution. Additionally, direct emissions of waste and discharges from facilities that can significantly contribute to the release of toxic soil and water pollutants, affecting the surrounding environment.
column16: Office buildings associated with renting and leasing motor vehicles can generate solid waste, which contributes to municipal solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather.
column17: Offices, warehouses, storage units and shops occupy land for operating their business.
column18: Warehouses and retail buildings require water for a variety of purposes such as cleaning, heating and cooling, and transportation.

column9: Wholesale of agricultural raw materials and live animals can release carbon dioxide and other indirect greenhouse gases from fuels and chemicals used during distribution, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Wholesale of machinery, equipment and supplies can result in air pollution due to the use of fuels and chemicals during distribution, leading to emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Harmful and polluting substances (potentially toxic heavy metals such as Pb, Cu, Cr, Fe, Ni, Zn) may be leached into the environment in wholesale trade. Runoff from roads can increase pollution in soils, wetlands and streams unless the runoff is treated. Additionally, water pollution can occur from fuels and chemicals used during distribution. Additionally, direct emissions of waste and discharges from facilities that can significantly contribute to the release of toxic soil and water pollutants, affecting the surrounding environment.
column16: Agricultural and live animals wholesale trade can generate solid waste, which contributes to municipal solid waste. Types of solid waste vary but include non-product outputs such as glass and plastic.
column17: Wholesale of agricultural raw materials and live animals occupy land for operating their business.
column18: Warehouses and retail buildings require water for a variety of purposes such as cleaning, heating and cooling, and transportation.
column19: Imported animals escape or are intentionally released and become invasive, contributing to the endangerment or extinction of native species.

column3: Air transport
column7: Passenger air transport can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to aircraft movement. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations such as altering migration patterns. Aircraft can also strike birds, e.g. during take-off.
column8: Airports may be built on 'reclaimed' freshwater areas such as swamps.
column9: Passenger air transport can release greenhouse gases during transport activities, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Airports may be built on 'reclaimed' seabed areas leading to changes in seabed morphology and hydrodynamic changes along the coastline.
column11: Passenger air transport activities emit non-GHG pollutants like CO, particulate matter, VOCs, and hydrocarbons. This results from fuel combustion, engine inefficiency, tire wear, fuel dumping, vehicle emissions, and storage tank releases. Other types of air pollutants can also be released in case of accidents.
column14: Passenger air transport can emit toxic pollutants through run-off of wastewater and contaminated water from operational procedures, such as spillage of de-icing agents, maintenance and painting chemicals, testing for fire equipment and fuel leakage and spillage from refuelling and storage.
column16: Passenger air transport generates solid waste. While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed (e.g. glass, plastic and organic waste from passenger trains).
column17: Airports and associated infrastructure such as waste and ground congestion occupy large areas of land.
column18: Passenger air transport uses water for many activities, including washing wheels, cleaning of aircraft, cooling, damping down dust, removing snow and firefighting.
column19: The global air travel network has been identified to be the most important form of travel in the spread of vector-borne diseases and the movement of damaging pest species.

column3: Warehousing and support activities for transportation
column5: Service activities incidental to air transportation
column7: Some service activities incidental to air transportation can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution (e.g. air traffic control lights, heavy machinery used in airway terminals). These can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Airports may be built on 'reclaimed' freshwater areas such as swamps.
column9: Some service activities incidental to air transportation can release greenhouse gases emissions (e.g. gas powered heavy machinery used in airway terminals), contributing to air pollution.
column10: Support activities for air transport occur within airports which may be built on 'reclaimed' seabed areas leading to changes in seabed morphology and hydrodynamic changes along the coastline
column11: Service activities incidental to air transportation emit non-GHG pollutants from use of vehicles and heavy machinery, for example emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Service activities incidental to air transportation can emit toxic pollutants through run-off of wastewater and contaminated water from the airfield and airway terminals. The toxic pollutants can be released for example from spillage of de-icing agents, maintenance and painting chemicals, testing for fire equipment and fuel leakage and spillage from refuelling and storage.
column16: Service activities incidental to air transportation produce large volumes of solid waste (e.g. passenger waste at airports or waste sand from maintenance of airfields). Some of the activities require use of office buildings or storage facilities, which produce different types of solid waste (e.g. glass, metal, plastic, paper, organic waste). While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed.
column17: Airports and associated infrastructure such as waste and ground congestion occupy large areas of land.
column18: Service activities incidental to air transport (e.g. airport terminals and airfields) use water for many activities, including washing wheels, and damping down dust.
