column2: Activities of households as employers; undifferentiated goods- and services-producing activities of households for own use
column3: Undifferentiated goods- and services-producing activities of private households for own use
column4: Undifferentiated goods-producing activities of private households for own use
column7: Cultivation of crops for private households can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution primarily due to the operation of agricultural machinery and the use of artificial lighting during various stages of the cultivation process. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Expansion of irrigated arable crops for private household use can lead to increased habitat modification, in particular through drainage (e.g. of wetlands) and conversion of natural habitats to croplands.
column9: Undifferentiated goods-producing activities of private households such as cultivation of crops can release greenhouse gases emissions (e.g. carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrogen oxides), contributing to air pollution.
column11: The cultivation of crops is a notable source of PM10 emissions, primarily during the farming stage due to the extensive use of chemical fertilizers and pesticides, as well as during the land preparation and harvesting stages influenced by the diesel fuel consumption of agricultural machinery.
column12: Household hunting for private use could require fishes and other animals, and making clothes needs fibers such as cotton.
column13: Undifferentiated goods-producing activities of private households for own use may involve extraction of minerals like phosphate, potash, and lime for cultivation and can result in negative impacts on species and habitats.
column14: The cultivation of crops uses pesticides and herbicides such as propanil, quinclorac, sulfonylurea, fipronil, cartap, niclosamide, and formaldehyde which can lead to toxic soil and water pollution.
column15: Households cultivating crops can use fertilizers like nitrogen (N) from ammonium sulfate, phosphorus (P) from rock phosphate, potassium (K) from potassium chloride, and urea from animal manure which can lead to nutrient soil and water pollution.
column16: Undifferentiated goods-producing activities can generate solid waste. The exact form of waste will vary but can include waste generated during the cultivation of crops such as plant residues, packaging materials, harvesting byproducts. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts through habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: The area of land occupied for the cultivation of crops varies widely depending on factors such as farming practices, yield potential, and regional conditions, but it can range from a few hectares to several thousand hectares for large-scale commercial production. Expansion of irrigated arable crops has led to increased habitat modification and conversion of natural habitats to croplands.
column18: A significant amount of water is required during the cultivation of crops and other food (including milk, cattle) due to potential water losses through the puddling process, surface evaporation, and percolation. Irrigation of arable crops leads to a substantial water footprint, which may be unsustainable in many areas of the world.
column19: Household activities can unintentionally spread invasive species through farming, landscape management, transport and other activities.

column3: Warehousing and support activities for transportation
column7: Cargo handling can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to vehicles (terrestrial, marine and airborne) that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations and lead to habitat fragmentation.
column8: Cargo handling for inland water transport requires use of freshwater areas for operation of harbours, piers and other facilities. Besides the fixed area use by infrastructure, the activities affect the movement of water transport vehicles in the locations.
column9: Some cargo handling activities can release greenhouse gas emissions (e.g. gas powered heavy machinery), contributing to air pollution.
column10: Cargo handling in marine ecosystems can cause physical changes in wave movement due to the movement of ships. This can alter the water column and seabed habitats.
column11: Some cargo handling activities involve use of vehicles or heavy machinery, which can release non-GHG air pollutants, for example emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Toxic soil and water pollutants may be leached into the environment in case of accidents.
column15: Spillages and leaks can occur during the handling of goods, which can include nutrient pollutants.
column16: Cargo handling generates large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather.  While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed.
column17: Handling of large volumes of cargo requires dedicated facilities and infrastructure that occupy significant areas of land.
column18: Cargo handling requires water for a variety of purposes, including cleaning vehicles and cooling facilities to store the cargo.
column19: Vehicles and containers used for transporting cargo can unintentionally introduce non-native invasive species.

column3: Warehousing and support activities for transportation
column7: N/A
column9: Some other transportation support activities can require use of car or other vehicles that release greenhouse gases, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Some other transportation support activities can require use of car or other vehicles that release non-GHG air pollutants.
column14: N/A
column15: Water and soil pollutants, including phosphorus and nitrogen, may leak from cargo in case of accidents.
column16: Office buildings, including those used by other transportation support activities, create large volumes of solid waste, which contribute to municipal solid waste. Types of solid waste vary but include non-product outputs such as glass and plastic. While most waste is collected by waste collection services, some solid waste may be improperly disposed.
column17: Land may be occupied for administrative buildings.
column18: Some activities supporting transportation (e.g. goods handling) require use of water for cleaning, heating and cooling of the facilities. If using an office, the use of the office requires large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping, and in some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies (e.g. server farms associated with cloud facilities).

column3: Warehousing and support activities for transportation
column5: Service activities incidental to water transportation
column7: Some service activities incidental to water transportation (e.g. operation of harbours, lighthouse activities) can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution.  Noise transmission can either be waterborne, airborne or structure-borne and can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Service activities incidental to water transport require use of freshwater areas for operation of harbours, piers, waterway locks and other facilities. Besides the fixed area use by infrastructure, the activities affect the movement of water transport vehicles in the locations.
column9: Service activities incidental to water transport can contribute to greenhouse gas emissions from facilities that are powered using on-site energy generators to use energy for the heating, cooling and lighting. Use of water and land vehicles (e.g. to service or tow boats in port) also releases greenhouse gas emissions.
column10: Service activities incidental to water transport require use of marine and coastal areas for operation of ports, piers, waterway locks and other facilities. Besides the fixed area footprint of infrastructure, their presence in the marine environment may also affect hydrodynamic and morphological features. This can alter water currents, sedimentation and seabed habitats.
column11: Service activities incidental to water transport can release non-GHG air pollutants (e.g., CFCs, HCFCs and HFCs) from buildings through cooling, refrigeration, or insulation materials. Use of water and land vehicles (e.g. to service or tow boats in port) also releases non-GHG air pollutants, for example emissions of carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Operation of harbours, piers, waterway locks and other infrastructure may release toxic pollutants into the water through waste and wastewater runoff as well as in case of accidents. Service activities incidental to water transportation may require use of land and water vehicles, both of which emit toxic pollutants through fuels. Ships also release toxic pollutants through leaching of antifouling paints and boat wash.
column15: Activities in harbours can emit nutrient pollutants which affect sediment and water.
column16: Operation of harbours may release solid waste into the water if this is not properly disposed. Service activities incidental to water transportation may require use of office buildings, which produce large volumes of solid waste (e.g. glass, metal, plastic, paper) that is not always correctly disposed.
column17: Terminal facilities, harbours, lighthouses occupy land.
column18: Service activities incidental to water transportation can use a significant amount of water, especially for docking and mooring services.

column3: Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery
column7: Waste collection can cause disturbances like noise pollution (i.e., waste collection vehicles) causing disruption or negatively affecingt species populations.
column9: Waste collection can release carbon dioxide and other indirect greenhouse gases from the use of waste collection vehicles in kerbside waste collection systems, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Emission of particulate matter (PM10) and other non-greenhouse air pollutants can occur from waste collection vehicles in kerbside waste collection systems.
column14: Underground vacuum waste collection can potentially lead to emissions of toxic soil and water pollutants in the event of pipe failure.
column15: Spillage and leakage during waste collection can release nutrient pollutants to water and soil.
column16: Waste collection activities generates its own waste residue (e.g. from containment materials) which need to be disposed of.
column17: Land may be occupied for waste collection.
column18: Waste collection requires water for washing vehicles, cleaning collection bins, dust suppression and facilities. Water abstraction can reduce local water supplies, which can increase the risk of drought and impact ecological habitats.
column19: Invasive species can spread during waste collection when seeds, spores, or other propagules are inadvertently transported with waste materials.

column2: Human health and social work activities
column3: Human health activities
column7: Medical and dental practice activities can cause disturbances such as moderate levels of light and noise pollution from practice buildings that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Medical and dental practice activities can release greenhouse gases emissions from anaesthetic gases and metered dose inhalers, and backup power generators for running equipments and facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Gaseous waste and discharges from facilities and operations contribute to environmental pollution. Backup power generators for running equipments can emit non-GHGs.
column14: Minerals, metals, medicines, contaminated dressing and other fibres and biomedical waste used in dental and medical procedures can dissolve and leach into the soil and generate toxic wastewater, which leads to soil pollution and contamination of receiving water bodies.
column16: Solid waste including single use consumables such as cotton and syringes and other non-recyclable materials are produced by medical and dental facilities. This can lead to habitat degradation from disposal of litter or soil and water pollution.
column17: Area of medical and dental hospitals and facilities.
column18: Water is used in a variety of medical and dental practice activities, including cleaning and disinfecting, patient care, food preparation, laundry and wastewater treatment. Office buildings associated with administration require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping.
column19: Biological and other types of waste matter coming from medical and dental practice activities can introduce infectious micro-organisms.

column3: Sports activities and amusement and recreation activities
column7: Sports activities can cause disturbances such as noise and light pollution from spectators, instruments and facilities such as sports stadiums and sports involving ATVs, motorcycles and snowmobiles, that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Freshwater sports activities including kayaking and canoing, can lead to the use of anchorages in freshwater areas, which can cause physical damage, especially in sensitive ecosystems such as mangroves.
column9: Sports activities can release emissions of greenhouse gases emissions during sporting tournaments and events, participants training, competitions, day trips, and through energy use to maintain facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Marine sports activities including competitive sailing, and motorboating, can lead to the use of anchorages and marinas in coastal and marine areas. Anchoring and marinas can cause physical damage to the seabed, especially in sensitive ecosystems such as seagrass beds or coral reefs.
column11: Non-GHG emissions can be released during sports activities as sporting tournaments and events, participants training, competitions, day trips, equipment and facilities.
column12: Some sports activities require biotic resources, an example of such sport is falconry, which involves trained birds of prey to hunt wild game. Falconry dependents on live prey for the birds to hunt, such as rabbits, hares, and small game birds, which can lead to an environment impact.
column14: The waste generated in some sports activities such as marathons, cycling races, and sporting tournaments and events can lead to soil and water pollution. For instance, water sports may require the use of chemicals to clean, protect, and run boats or motorboats. These chemicals (e.g. zinc) can deteriorate the pH level of water which affects marine wildlife.
column16: Sports activities such as marathons, cycling races, and sporting tournaments and events can generate large amounts of solid waste, including food and beverage containers, packaging, and promotional materials.
column17: Some sports activities can take up a large amount of land which may lead to deforestation and habitat fragmentation.
column18: Water is required for athletes hydration to maintain their performance and avoid heat exhaustion and dehydration. Some sports activities such as football, rugby, and field hockey also require regular watering to maintain the quality of the playing surface. Water is also required for sanitation, cleaning and maintenance of facilities, arenas and stadiums.

column3: Sports activities and amusement and recreation activities
column7: Other amusement and recreation activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of attractions e.g. fairgrounds and use by guests and vehicles that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Other amusement and recreation activities such as events, water rides, games, shows and exhibits can take place in freshwater ecosystems.
column9: Other amusement and recreation activities using facilities that are powered using on-site energy generators can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for sound systems and rides, contributing to air pollution.
column10: Recreational boating, including sailing, motorboating, and yachting, can lead to the use of anchorages in coastal and marine areas. Anchoring and marinas can cause physical damage to the seabed, especially in sensitive ecosystems such as seagrass beds or coral reefs.
column11: Gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment, collectively contribute to environmental pollution, emitting non-greenhouse gases.
column12: Recreational fishing can put pressure on fish populations, especially if it is not properly regulated. Overfishing, excessive catch-and-release practices, and illegal fishing can deplete fish stocks, disrupt aquatic ecosystems, and harm the overall biodiversity of rivers, lakes, and oceans.
column14: Some amusement and recreation activities generate wastewater that may contain contaminants such as oil, grease, heavy metals, or other chemicals. If not properly treated or disposed of, this wastewater can be discharged into water bodies and soils, leading to pollution and ecological damage.
column16: Office buildings associated with service provision create solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Improper disposal of this waste can contribute to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Amusement and recreation activities can occupy land.
column18: Other recreational activities such as public and private swimming pools require regular water replenishment and maintenance. Other activities such as golf courses require extensive irrigation which leads to a substantial water footprint, which may be unsustainable in many areas of the world.
column19: Camping and outdoor activities involve moving firewood, which can harbour invasive insects, such as emerald ash borer and Asian longhorned beetle. When infested firewood is transported to new areas, these invasive species can be introduced and cause significant damage to native trees and forests.
column20:

column2: Water supply; sewerage, waste management and remediation activities
column3: Waste collection, treatment and disposal activities; materials recovery
column7: Waste disposal and treatment activities can cause disturbances like noise, light and odour pollution due to the operation of disposal facilities and waste transportation, that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Waste treatment and disposal can release greenhouse gases emissions from the organic waste in landfills (e.g., food scraps and yard trimmings) and treatment methods (e.g. incineration), contributing to air pollution.
column11: Waste treatment and disposal can result in non-greenhouse gases, releasing air pollutants like particulate matter, sulfur dioxide, nitrogen oxides, volatile organic compounds, and heavy metals.
column14: Inadequate containment or disposal of hazardous waste can cause the emission of harmful substances like heavy metals, chemical contaminants, pesticides, and other toxins into the soil and water bodies.
column15: Inadequate treatment processes or improper disposal methods of waste treatment and disposal activities can result in the release of nutrient pollutants and substances into the soil and water.
column16: Waste treatment and disposal activities can generate solid waste through activities such as the disposal to landfill sites. Types of solid waste vary but include non-product outputs such as oil, debris, discarded equipment, packaging, and other byproducts of the remediation process.
column17: Land may be occupied for waste treatment and disposal.
column18: Waste treatment and disposal requires water use to treat wastewater and to dispose of solid waste.
column19: Waste treatment and disposal activities can introduce invasive species if not handled and disposed of properly. If precautions are not taken, these species can be transported to new areas via waste materials, causing harm to native ecosystems.

column3: Water transport
column7: Inland water transport can cause disturbances like noise pollution due to the operation of vehicles and machinery. Noise transmission can either be waterborne, airborne or structure-borne and can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column8: Inland water transport requires use of freshwater areas (e.g. lakes, rivers and man-made waterways) for the movement of water vehicles as well as for harbours, piers and other infrastructure. Due to the interconnected nature of freshwater ecosystems, inland water transport can also affect shoreline areas (e.g. by altering sediment dynamics).
column9: Inland water transport can release greenhouse gases from transport as well as to produce energy when docked in port (e.g. for lighting, heating, cooling, ventilation), contributing to air pollution.
column11: Inland water transport can release non-GHG air pollutants from transport as well as to produce energy when docked in port (e.g. for lighting, heating, cooling, ventilation). Non-GHG air pollutants emitted by ships include carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Inland water transport can emit toxic pollutants through (1) chemicals used for washing of ships that can affect erosion of estuaries, sediment resuspension, and turbidity, (2) oil and fuel leakage from motors and cargo, (3) spillage of antifouling paints.
column15: Water and soil pollutants, including phosphorus and nitrogen, may leak from cargo in case of accidents.
column16: Inland water transport activities generate solid waste. The exact type of waste will vary but can include ship related organic, domestic, and operational waste. This can lead to habitat degradation or water pollution from improper disposal.
column17: N/A
column18: Inland water transport uses water for a variety of purposes, including cooling, ballasting, washing and firefighting.
column19: Inland water transportation may cause population changes due to collisions with wildlife. It's also a vector of unintentional species introduction, promoting invasion of non-native species that can alter (and impact) species populations.

column3: Gambling and betting activities
column7: Gambling and betting activities can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution due to the operation of casinos (including floating ones) that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Gambling and betting activities can release greenhouse gases emissions through the energy use and luxurious service in casino, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Gaseous waste, discharges from facilities and operations, as well as emissions from backup power generators used to run equipment, collectively contribute to environmental pollution, emitting non-greenhouse gases.
column14: If using facilities and buildings, gambling and betting activities produce waste and discharges that can be emitted into the surrounding environment, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Buildings associated with service provision create solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic and paper and cardboard. Improper disposal of this waste can contribute to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Casinos can occupy large areas of land.
column18: Casinos and betting shops require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. The water used contributes to water stress, especially in areas where water resources are already limited.
column20:

column11: Activities of business, employers and professional membership organizations conducted from an office building that is powered using on-site energy generators can produce significant non-GHG emissions as well as emissions associated with cooling, refrigeration, or insulation materials.
column14: N/A

column18: Office buildings associated with administration require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies (e.g. server farms associated with cloud facilities).

column18: Office buildings associated with administration require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies (e.g. server farms associated with cloud facilities).
column19: Activities related to animal welfare or religious reasons can lead to the unintentional release of invasive species e.g., American lobsters native to Canada and USA mass released in English Channel in UK.

Potential emissions through dumping and incineration of waste computer parts that cannot be reused or repaired.
column11: The gaseous waste and discharges from facilities as well as backup power generators used to operate equipment can emit non-greenhouse gases.
column14: Repair of computers and communication equipment produce potential emissions through dumping and incineration of waste computer parts that cannot be reused or repaired.

column7: Repair of personal and household goods can cause disturbances such as noise and light pollution from people, buildings or outdoor environment that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Repair of personal and household goods using an office building that is powered using on-site energy generators can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: The gaseous waste and discharges from facilities as well as backup power generators used to operate equipment can emit non-greenhouse gases.
column14: Repair of personal and household goods could produce potential emissions through dumping and incineration of waste parts that cannot be reused or repaired.
column16: Computer repair activities generate solid waste due to non-repairable components, including from hazardous metals and plastic waste as well as non-toxic components such as glass and rubber.

column3: Other personal service activities
column7: If taking place in a building, other personal service activities can cause disturbances such as noise and light pollution from people, office buildings or outdoor environment that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Some personal service activities, for example sauna and steam baths, can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy used for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Personal service activities conducted from an office building can contribute to non-GHG emissions such as halocarbons, CFCs, HCFCs, and hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs), due to their applications for cooling, refrigeration, and in the case of halocarbons, insulation materials.
column14: ND
column16: Office buildings associated with service provision can generate solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather.
column17: If the organisation has offices and/or service centres they will occupy an area of land.
column18: Office buildings require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies (e.g. server farms associated with cloud facilities).

column4: Activities of households as employers of domestic personnel
column7: ND
column9: ND
column11: Chemical pollutants from cleaning supplies (called volatile organic compounds, or VOCs) can be emitted into the atmosphere, creating a source of air pollution.
column14: Water pollutants generated from household activities can cause environmental pollution, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Activities of households as employers of domestic personnel generate solid waste. The exact form of solid waste will vary but can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, paper and cardboard, plastic, wood and rubber. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts through habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Households occupy land.
column18: Households require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies.

column3: Water transport
column7: Sea and coastal water transport can cause noise pollution (either waterborne, airborne or structureborne) due to the operation of vehicles and machinery, most significantly in port areas associated with cargo handling. This can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Sea and coastal water transport can release greenhouse gases from transport as well as to produce energy when docked in port (e.g. for lighting, heating, cooling, ventilation), contributing to air pollution.
column10: Sea and coastal water transport requires use of marine areas for the movement of ships, which can alter hydrodynamic features (e.g. ship wake) and seabed habitats. Harbours, piers and other infrastructure also use seabed areas. Dredging of the seabed within harbours may be necessary to maintain navigability.
column11: Sea and coastal water transport can release non-GHG air pollutants from transport as well as to produce energy when docked in port (e.g. for lighting, heating, cooling, ventilation). Non-GHG air pollutants emitted by ships include carbon monoxide (CO), hydrocarbons, nitrogen oxide (NOx), sulphur dioxide (SO2), particulates, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs).
column14: Sea and coastal water transport can emit toxic pollutants through (1) chemicals used for washing of ships that can affect erosion of estuaries, sediment resuspension, and turbidity, (2) oil and fuel leakage from motors and cargo, (3) spillage of antifouling paints.
column15: Water and soil pollutants, including phosphorus and nitrogen, may leak from cargo in case of accidents.
column16: Sea and coastal water transport activities generate solid waste. The exact type of waste will vary but can include ship related organic, domestic, and operational waste. This can lead to habitat degradation or water pollution from improper disposal.
column17: N/A
column18: Sea and coastal water transport uses water for a variety of purposes, including cooling, ballasting, washing and firefighting.
column19: Marine transportation may cause population changes due to collisions with wildlife. Shipping, and ballast water in particular, is a vector of unintentional species introduction in estuarine and coastal marine systems, promoting invasion of non-native species that can alter (and impact) species populations.

column2: Activities of households as employers; undifferentiated goods- and services-producing activities of households for own use
column3: Undifferentiated goods- and services-producing activities of private households for own use
column4: Undifferentiated service-producing activities of private households for own use
column7: Undifferentiated service-producing activities of private households for own use activities include cooking, teaching, caring for household members and other services produced by the household for its own subsistence. This can cause disturbances like noise and light pollution, that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Household activities such as cooking can release greenhouse gases emissions, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Household activities such as cooking can generate air pollution, such as carbon monoxide and formaldehyde.
column12: Household activities such as cooking required food resources, and if cooked on woodstoves or fireplaces these may require timber.
column14: Undifferentiated service-producing activities of private households for own use produce waste and discharges that can be emitted into the surrounding environment, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Undifferentiated service-producing activities can generate solid waste. The exact form of waste will vary but can include waste generated during the cultivation of crops such as plant residues, packaging materials, harvesting byproducts. This can lead to adverse environmental impacts through habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Households occupy land.
column18: Water is used for activities such as cooking, cleaning, laundry, bathing and gardening.

column2: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies
column3: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies
column4: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies
column7: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies can cause disturbances such as light pollution from office buildings that can disrupt or negatively affect species populations.
column9: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies using an office building that is powered using on-site energy generators can release greenhouse gases emissions from energy use for the heating, cooling and lighting the facilities, contributing to air pollution.
column11: Activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies conducted from an office building that is powered using on-site energy generators can produce significant non-GHG emissions as well as emissions associated with cooling, refrigeration, or insulation materials.
column14: If using an office, activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies produce waste and discharges that can be emitted into the surrounding environment, affecting soil and water bodies.
column16: Office buildings associated with service provision create large volumes of solid waste. The exact types of solid waste produced will vary, but these can include non-product outputs such as glass, metal, plastic, paper and cardboard, wood, and rubber and leather. Solid waste treatment and disposal can lead to habitat degradation and land contamination.
column17: Offices associated to activities of extraterritorial organizations and bodies occupy land for running their operations.
column18: Office buildings associated with administration require large volumes of water for a variety of purposes such as restrooms, heating and cooling, and landscaping. In some instances the water is extracted directly from local water bodies.

column2: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column3: Electricity, gas, steam and air conditioning supply
column4: Electric power generation, transmission and distribution
column7: Transmission lines can cause disturbances from noise pollution and electromagnetic waves.
column8: Transmission lines may disturb freshwater sources such as rivers, or bored beneath a waterway.
column9: Transmission and distribution of electricity emits GHG emissions such as sulphur hexafluoride.
column10: Transmission and distribution of electricity may include underwater cables that could disturb the area of seabed.
column11: Transmission and distribution of electricity can emit non-GHG air pollutants, such as toxic emissions released when power lines overheat or catch fire.
column14: Transmission and distribution of electricity can lead to contamination of soils through the spillage of cable oil, or some residues of the activity.
column16: Transmission and distribution of electricity can generate solid waste, for example from the cleaning of substations and replacement of transmission lines.
column17: Power lines used to distribute energy contribute to habitat fragmentation and sub-stations have a local land use footprint.
column18: Transmission and distribution of electricity may use water for cooling systems.
